name: Dynamic Wearable Health Monitoring
description: This use case enables older adults with varying privacy preferences and mobility needs to use small, comfortable wearables that continuously track vital signs and activity levels. Caregivers receive tailored, real-time health notifications while respecting the older adults' data sharing settings, supporting personalized care and physical engagement.
scenario:
Elena Rivera, a tech-curious woman in her sixties with mild mobility issues, eagerly strapped on her new ALFRED wearable, a sleek and lightweight device she barely noticed on her wrist. She was excited about the continuous monitoring it promised, especially since she loved pushing herself to try harder exercises and stay active. That morning, ALFRED suggested a new water-drinking reminder and a light stretching routine tailored just for her. Elena responded aloud, “Let’s do the advanced stretch today,” feeling motivated by the system’s encouragement and the real-time feedback on her activity levels.

Meanwhile, Olivia, a retired social worker living alone, was less enthusiastic about the technology. She had reluctantly agreed to wear a similar device but had configured ALFRED to limit notifications and block any apps or reminders she found intrusive. When ALFRED softly nudged her to do some mild movement, Olivia dismissed the suggestion with a curt voice command, “No, thank you.” She was uncomfortable sharing any health data, having explicitly blocked all data sharing even with her caregivers. The device sat quietly on her wrist, acting more as a passive tracker than an interactive assistant, respecting her wish to keep everything formal and minimal.

Sarah Thompson, an informal caregiver responsible for both Elena and Olivia, accessed the ALFRED dashboard from her tablet. She admired Elena’s willingness to engage with the exercises and appreciated the detailed real-time vitals and activity reports streaming from Elena’s device. Sarah sent a quick encouraging message through ALFRED’s communication channel, knowing Elena would appreciate the informal tone. However, Olivia’s data was far more limited—Sarah only received minimal vitals and no activity updates due to Olivia’s strict privacy settings. Sarah found this frustrating, as it limited her ability to intervene proactively. She had to rely on occasional phone check-ins, which Olivia often avoided.

Despite these tensions, the system’s adaptability allowed each woman to maintain their autonomy. Elena thrived with ALFRED’s proactive coaching and open data sharing, feeling supported and motivated. Olivia, on the other hand, valued her privacy above all and used ALFRED quietly, only allowing the bare minimum of interaction. Sarah navigated these differences daily, balancing her desire to provide attentive care with respect for each client’s boundaries. The wearables quietly bridged their worlds—sometimes in harmony, sometimes in silent compromise.
